intro: Hasteola robertiorum, commonly known as the Robert's beardgrass, is a member of the grass family Poaceae. It is a small annual plant characterized by its slender, hair-like leaves and tiny, spikelet-bearing inflorescences. Native to the western United States, it thrives in dry, open habitats such as grasslands and disturbed soils. The plant typically grows to a height of 10–30 centimeters and produces small, wind-pollinated flowers. Its botanical features make it an important component of its native ecosystem, supporting various insect and bird species.
